Think of the \(n\times n\) **covariance matrix \(\Sigma(t)\)** of a Gaussian heat kernel as the quadratic form that tells you

\[
d_{t}^{2}(x,y)\;=\;(x-y)^{\!\top}\Sigma(t)^{-1}(x-y),
\qquad 
p_{t}(x)\;=\;\frac{e^{-\tfrac12d_{t}^{2}(x,0)}}{\sqrt{(2\pi)^{n}\det\Sigma(t)}} .
\]

The metric \(d_t\) evolves smoothly with \(t\) (indeed \(\partial_t\Sigma=2I\)), and the **dimension** you read off from the on-diagonal heat kernel

\[
p_{t}(0)\sim (4\pi t)^{-n/2}
\]

is the exponent of \(t\) in that prefactor.

For singular or heavy-tailed limits the second moment diverges, so \(\Sigma\) disappears.  The right replacement is the **intrinsic pseudo-metric** that comes with the **Dirichlet (energy) form** of the limiting semigroup.  Three archetypes illustrate how this works and why the resulting dimension can be any real number in \((0,1)\).

---

### 1.   α-stable kernels (fat-tailed, translation invariant)

*Generator & energy*   The isotropic symmetric α-stable semigroup has generator  
\[
L_\alpha = -(-\Delta)^{\alpha/2}, \qquad 0<\alpha<2,
\]
and Dirichlet form  
\[
\mathcal E_\alpha(f)=\frac12\!\iint_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!
\frac{|f(x)-f(y)|^{2}}{\|x-y\|^{n+\alpha}}\;dx\,dy .
\]

*Intrinsic distance*   Set  
\[
d_\alpha(x,y)\;=\;\Bigl(\mathcal E_\alpha(\phi)\Bigr)^{1/\alpha}
\quad\text{for every Lipschitz }\phi\text{ with }\phi(x)-\phi(y)=1.
\]
This **quasi-metric** satisfies \(d_\alpha(cx,cy)=c\,d_\alpha(x,y)\) and the
triangle inequality up to a constant.  When \(\alpha=2\) it is exactly the
Euclidean metric encoded by a covariance matrix; when \(\alpha<2\) it codifies
the scale of the *jumps* rather than the variance.

*Dimension*   The heat kernel scales as  
\[
p_t^{(\alpha)}(0)\sim t^{-n/\alpha},
\]
so the **effective dimension** is \(n_\text{eff}=n/\alpha\), which need not be
integer.  In one dimension you can continuously dial the limit between a
Dirac mass (\(\alpha\!\downarrow\!0\)) and the Gaussian (\(\alpha=2\)).

---

### 2.   Self-similar fractals (e.g. Cantor, Sierpiński)

*Generator & energy*   On a post-critically finite fractal \(K\) there is a
unique (up to scale) resistance form \( (\mathcal E,\mathcal F) \) satisfying
a self-similar renormalisation equation.  It plays the rôle of
\(\int|\nabla f|^{2}\) even though no classical derivatives exist.

*Intrinsic distance*   The **resistance metric**
\[
R(x,y)\;=\;\sup_{\substack{f\in\mathcal F\\ \mathcal E(f)\le 1}}
|f(x)-f(y)|
\]
is genuine (finite, symmetric, triangle-satisfying) and reduces to the
Euclidean one on intervals.  Under the IFS maps it contracts by the same ratio
that the set itself does.

*Dimension*   The associated heat kernel obeys the sub-Gaussian law  
\(p_t(x,x)\asymp t^{-d_s/2}\) with  
\[
d_s = \frac{2d_f}{d_w},
\]
where \(d_f\) is Hausdorff and \(d_w>2\) is the **walk dimension**
(recording how fast diffusion spreads).  For the middle-third Cantor set
\(d_f=\log2/\log3\) and \(d_w=\log5/\log3\), giving \(d_s\approx0.73\).

---

### 3.   Multiplicative cascades & multifractal measures

*Generator & energy*   There is no global semigroup; instead one studies the
martingale sequence \(\mu_n\) produced by random weights.  The quadratic form
is replaced by the **\(q\)-th moment structure function**
\[
S_q(r)=\mathbb E\!\bigl[\mu(B(x,r))^{\,q}\bigr]\sim r^{\tau(q)},
\]
whose *Legendre transform* yields the multifractal spectrum.

*Intrinsic scale gauge*   Fix a “Hölder gauge’’  
\(d_\beta(x,y)=|x-y|^{\beta}\) with \(\beta\) chosen so that
\(\mu\bigl(B(x,r)\bigr)\approx r^{d_\mu}\) a.s.  The exponent \(d_\mu\) is the
\(q\!=\!1\) point of \(\tau\).

*Dimension*   The limit measure is singular, non-atomic, and its
**information/metric dimension** is exactly that \(d_\mu\in(0,1)\).
Evolution of \(S_q(r)\) with the cascade depth \(n\) replaces the covariance
flow.

> **Covariance ⇒ Dirichlet form:**  
>  In any metric-measure space \((X,d,m)\) that supports a Markov semigroup
>  \(P_t\) with generator \(L\) and Dirichlet form \(\mathcal E\),  
>  the quadratic form \(v^\top\Sigma v\) is replaced by

>  \(d_{\mathcal E}(x,y)=\sup\{f(x)-f(y):\mathcal E(f)\le1\}\).

For classical Gaussians \(\mathcal E(f)=\int|\nabla f|^{2}\) and \(d=n\).
For α-stable kernels, \(\mathcal E\) is non-local and \(d=n/\alpha\).

### 1  How a measure gets a “dimension”

Take any probability measure µ on a space with a distance d.  
Look at a ball of radius r around a typical point:

\[
\text{mass}\bigl(B_r(x)\bigr)\;\sim\; C\,r^{\,d_\mu}\quad (r\downarrow0).
\]

The exponent \(d_\mu\) is the **dimension of the measure**.  
For a Dirac mass the ball already contains the whole mass once \(r>0\), so
\(d_\mu=0\).  
If the measure is the ordinary length on a line, \(d_\mu=1\).  
Anything in between is possible.

---

### 2  Getting non-integer \(d_\mu\) by “generalising Dirac”

Start with Lebesgue measure on \([0,1]\) and *split–shrink–reweight* repeatedly (Cantor construction, Bernoulli convolution, multiplicative cascade, …).  
After infinitely many steps the limit measure lives on a dust-like set and its mass scales as \(r^{d_\mu}\) with a non-integer \(d_\mu\).  
In symbols:

\[
\mu_{n+1}= \sum_{i} p_i\,T_{i\#}\mu_n,\qquad
\text{with contractions }T_i.
\]

Letting \(n\to\infty\) plays the same rôle variance → 0 plays for the Gaussian that converges to a Dirac—only now the limit is *singular but spread out*, not a single point.

---

### 3  Getting non-integer *multivariate* dimensions by “generalising Euclidean metrics”

For a Gaussian, the covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) turns the usual distance \(\|x-y\|\) into the quadratic form
\((x-y)^{\!\top}\Sigma^{-1}(x-y)\).  
Replace that quadratic form by another rule for measuring jumps and you get a new distance whose balls have volume \(\sim r^{d}\) with a fractional \(d\).  Two common choices:

| Replacement for the quadratic form | Resulting distance | Effective dimension \(d\) |
|---|---|---|
| **α-stable kernel** – cost of a jump of size h is \(|h|^{\alpha}\) with \(0<\alpha<2\) | \(d_\alpha(x,y)\propto|x-y|\) but diffusion time scales like \(r^{\alpha}\) | \(d=\frac{n}{\alpha}\) in \(\mathbb R^{n}\) (fractional) |
| **Resistance metric on a self-similar set** (e.g. Sierpiński gasket) | Distance defined by minimal “energy’’ needed to separate two points | \(d=\) *spectral* dimension of the fractal, typically non-integer |

Those metrics reduce to the Euclidean one when \(\alpha=2\) or when the set is a smooth manifold but give fractional scaling otherwise.

* **Yes, you can obtain non-integer-dimensional measures** by

* **Yes, you can obtain non-integer-dimensional multivariate laws** by

The unifying principle is **scaling**: choose either

* a mass rule whose small-radius behaviour is \(r^{d}\), or
* a distance rule whose small-ball volume is \(r^{d}\).

In both cases the exponent \(d\) need not be an integer, and that is what people mean when they speak of “fractional-dimensional’’ distributions or spaces.

1. **Pick the target dimension \(d\).**

2. **Decide how many pieces \(m\ge 2\)** you want to keep at every stage of the construction (two pieces is the simplest).

### Basic rule

Pick a point \(x\) and look at the mass in a ball of radius \(r\):

\[
\mu\!\bigl(B_r(x)\bigr)\;\propto\; r^{\,d}\quad\text{as }r\downarrow0 .
\]

* The exponent \(d\) itself **is the dimension**.

So “power-law exponent’’ ↔ “dimension’’ directly.

---

### Where the reciprocal shows up

When you design a self-similar construction you often start with:

* keep \(m\) pieces each step  
* shrink each piece by a factor \(r\)

and then solve  
\[
d=\frac{\log m}{\log(1/r)}.
\]

Here \(1/r\) sits in the *denominator*, so people sometimes say “dimension is the inverse of the shrink-exponent’’—but that is just algebra inside this particular formula, not a general principle.

---

**Bottom line:** in the simple scaling law  
\[
\text{mass} \;\approx\; (\text{size})^{\;d},
\]
the power-law exponent **\(d\) *is* the dimension**. No inversion needed.

## Why it works (in plain terms)

| step | what you do | what it means |

| **1  Pick the dimension** \(d\in(0,1)\) | decide how “thin’’ you want the space to be | |
| **2  Keep \(m\) pieces each round** (most people take \(m=2\) for simplicity) | at every iteration you keep \(m\) disjoint sub-pieces | |
| **3  Compute the shrink factor** \(r=m^{-1/d}\) | so that the formula “\(m\) pieces, each \(r\)–times as long’’ exactly solves \(d=\log m/\log(1/r)\) | |

**What \( \varphi \) is**

* \( \varphi_{X}(k) \;\equiv\; \mathbb E\!\left[e^{\,i k X}\right] \) for a real-valued random variable \(X\).  
* It is called the **characteristic function** of the distribution of \(X\).  
  *You can think of it as the “frequency-domain fingerprint’’ of the law.*

---

**Link to the density**

If the probability law of \(X\) has a density \(p(x)\), the two are just Fourier transforms of each other:

\[
\boxed{\;
\varphi(k)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{\,ikx}\,p(x)\,dx,
\qquad
p(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-ikx}\,\varphi(k)\,dk
\;}
\]

So knowing \( \varphi \) *completely determines* \(p\) (and vice-versa).

---

**Why we wrote \( \varphi_{\alpha,s}(k)=\exp\!\bigl(-s^{\alpha}|k|^{\alpha}\bigr) \)**

* That single formula is the characteristic function of the entire family of **symmetric α-stable laws**.  
  * \( \alpha \) (between 0 and 2) sets how heavy the tails are.  
  * \( s \) is a scale—play the same rôle a standard deviation plays for a Gaussian.

Once you know \( \varphi_{\alpha,s} \), you can—at least in principle—plug it into the inverse-Fourier formula above to get the density \( p_{\alpha,s}(x) \).

### 1 Inverse Fourier transform of  
\(\displaystyle\varphi_{\alpha,s}(k)=\exp\!\bigl(-s^{\alpha}|k|^{\alpha}\bigr)\)

For every \(\alpha\in(0,2]\) and scale \(s>0\) the real-space density is

\[
\boxed{\;
p_{\alpha,s}(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}
e^{-ikx}\,e^{-s^{\alpha}|k|^{\alpha}}\;dk
\;=\;
\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{0}^{\infty}
\cos(kx)\,e^{-s^{\alpha}k^{\alpha}}\;dk
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

Equation (1) *defines* the symmetric \(\alpha\)-stable density.  Except for a few \(\alpha\) it cannot be written in elementary functions, but it is well-behaved (positive, integrates to 1) and easily evaluated numerically.

---

### 2 Closed-form cases you already know

| \(\alpha\) | density obtained from (1) | tail \(p_{\alpha,s}(x)\sim\) |
|------------|---------------------------|------------------------------|
| \(0\) | Dirac \(\delta(x)\) | — |
| \(1\) | Cauchy \(\displaystyle\frac{s}{\pi\bigl(s^{2}+x^{2}\bigr)}\) | \(\sim |x|^{-2}\) |
| \(2\) | Gaussian \(\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{4\pi s^{2}}}\,e^{-x^{2}/(4s^{2})}\) | \(\sim e^{-x^{2}}\) |

(All other \(\alpha\) interpolate smoothly between these extremes; their tails behave like \(|x|^{-(1+\alpha)}\).)

A **full** one-dimensional stable law is specified by four numbers
\((\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\mu)\)  

* stability index \(\alpha\in(0,2]\)  
* skewness \(\beta\in[-1,1]\)  
* scale \(\gamma>0\)  
* location \(\mu\in\mathbb R\)

with characteristic function  
\[

-\,\gamma^{\alpha}|k|^{\alpha}\bigl[1-i\beta\,\operatorname{sgn}(k)\tan\tfrac{\pi\alpha}{2}\bigr]
+i\mu k
\Bigr)\quad(\alpha\neq1).
\]

In the *symmetric, centred* case we have  
\(\beta=0,\;\mu=0\), so \(\gamma=s\) and the characteristic function reduces to the single-parameter form \(\varphi_{\alpha,s}\) used above.  Multi-variate versions are built by taking independent 1-D axes, optionally rotating with an orthogonal matrix, exactly as you do with Gaussians.

*Equation (1) is the inverse Fourier transform you asked for; varying the lone exponent \(\alpha\) (and the scale \(s\)) sweeps continuously from a point mass (\(\alpha=0\)) through heavy-tailed power-law densities to the ordinary Gaussian (\(\alpha=2\)).*

**Key fact**

The way a density \(p(x)\) dies off for large \(|x|\) is dictated by how quickly its characteristic function  
\[
\varphi(k)=\mathbb E[e^{ikX}]

shrinks as \(|k|\to\infty\) **and** by whether \(\varphi(k)\) can be continued to imaginary values \(k=\pm i\tau\).  

---

### 1 Gaussian (\(\alpha=2\))  

*Characteristic function* \(\displaystyle\varphi(k)=e^{-\sigma^{2}k^{2}/2}\).  
This is an **entire** function: it is finite for every complex \(k\). Therefore a moment-generating function \(M(\tau)=\varphi(i\tau)\) exists for all \(\tau\).  
*Consequence* Because the Laplace transform is finite, the inverse-Fourier integral that produces \(p(x)\)

\[
p(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-ikx}\varphi(k)\,dk
\]

can be shifted up to the imaginary axis (steepest-descent), and its leading term is the exponential of the saddle-point value.  The result is the familiar

\[
p(x)\;\sim\;\exp\!\bigl(-\,c\,x^{2}\bigr)\quad(|x|\to\infty).
\]

That “faster than any power’’ decay is the hallmark of **finite exponential moments**.

---

### 2 Stable laws with \(0<\alpha<2\)

*Characteristic function* \(\displaystyle\varphi(k)=e^{-s^{\alpha}|k|^{\alpha}}\).  
For non-integer \(\alpha\) this function **cannot be extended** to a strip around the imaginary axis; \(M(\tau)=\varphi(i\tau)\) is infinite as soon as \(\tau\ne0\).  

*Consequence* Because the contour cannot be deformed off the real axis, the dominant contribution to the inverse-transform comes from **small \(k\)**, where \(\varphi(k)\approx1-s^{\alpha}|k|^{\alpha}\).  A standard Tauberian calculation (essentially the Fourier version of “power ⇄ power’’) gives

\[
p_{\alpha,s}(x)\;\sim\;C_{\alpha}\,s^{\alpha}\,|x|^{-(1+\alpha)}
\qquad(|x|\to\infty).
\]

The power-law tail is therefore the signature of **zero exponential moments**: heavy jumps dominate the statistics, so the probability of a large excursion falls only polynomially.

---

### 3 Dirac (\(\alpha=0\))

Here \(\varphi(k)\equiv1\).  All analytic continuation is lost, the inverse-transform collapses to \(\delta(x)\), and the “tail’’ is literally zero beyond the origin.

---

### Rule of thumb

* **Analytic continuation to \(k=i\tau\) exists → exponential (or faster) tail.**  
  Gaussians sit at \(\alpha=2\).

* **No such continuation but characteristic function still tends to \(0\) → power-law tail.**  
  Symmetric \(\alpha\)-stable laws with \(0<\alpha<2\) give \(|x|^{-(1+\alpha)}\).

* **Characteristic function identically \(1\) → all mass at a point.**  
  Dirac corresponds to \(\alpha=0\).

* **\(t=0\)** \(\varphi_0\equiv1\Rightarrow p_0=\delta_0\) (Dirac).

* **\(\alpha=2\)** \(p_t^{(2)}\) is the usual Gaussian with variance \(2t\).

## Process viewpoint  

The kernel \(p_t^{(\alpha)}\) is the transition density of the **symmetric \(\alpha\)-stable Lévy process** \(X_t\) whose generator is the *fractional Laplacian*

\[
\partial_t u(t,x)= -\,(-\Delta)^{\alpha/2}u(t,x),\qquad u(0,x)=\delta_0.
\]

*   As **time \(t\downarrow0\)** the paths barely move, so the law collapses to the Dirac spike exactly as the shrinking-variance Gaussian does.  
*   For fixed \(\alpha\)<2 the tails remain power-law; the cloud just *widens* with the similarity scale \(t^{1/\alpha}\).  
*   Setting **\(\alpha=2\)** recovers Brownian motion and its Gaussian heat kernel.

Thus the whole range \(0<\alpha\le2\) sits on one continuous semigroup \( \{p_t^{(\alpha)}\}_{t\ge0}\) with

\[
p_t^{(\alpha)} * p_s^{(\alpha)} = p_{t+s}^{(\alpha)},\qquad 
\lim_{t\to0} p_t^{(\alpha)} = \delta_0.
\]

Let \(\{Y_j\}\) be i.i.d. with heavy tails \(\mathbb P(|Y_j|>x)\sim Cx^{-\alpha}\).

\[

Not in any strict, one-to-one sense.

### What a ket \(\lvert\psi\rangle\) is
A ket is simply a unit vector in a complex Hilbert space.  In the position representation
\[
\psi(x)=\langle x \!\mid\!\psi\rangle ,
\]
and the Born rule turns it into a probability *density*
\[
\rho(x)=|\psi(x)|^{2}.
\]
The ket, however, also carries the *phase* of \(\psi(x)=\sqrt{\rho(x)}\,e^{iS(x)/\hbar}\); that extra phase is essential for interference and for operators like momentum \(-i\hbar\nabla\).

### What the (classical) score function is  
For an ordinary probability density \(p(x)\) the score is
\[
s(x)=\nabla_{x}\log p(x)=\frac{\nabla p(x)}{p(x)} .
\]
It is a real vector field that captures how sharply the log-density changes in space; it underlies the Fisher metric, score-matching estimators, diffusion-model dynamics, etc.

### How they meet in the position basis
Write the wavefunction in polar form:
\[
\psi(x)=\sqrt{\rho(x)}\,e^{iS(x)/\hbar}.
\]
Then
\[
\nabla\log\rho(x)=2\,\nabla\log|\psi(x)| .
\]
So the *magnitude* part of the ket determines the classical score up to a factor 2.  
But:

* the phase \(S(x)\) is invisible to the score function;
* conversely, knowing only \(s(x)\) never tells you the phase, so you cannot reconstruct the full ket.

Hence there is at best a **partial** correspondence: the score function encodes the gradient information of the ket’s modulus, but it misses half the quantum information.

### Quantum analogue of the score  
In quantum statistics one often introduces the **symmetric logarithmic derivative** (SLD) \(L_\theta\), defined by
\[
\partial_{\theta}\rho_\theta=\tfrac12\!\bigl(L_\theta\,\rho_\theta+\rho_\theta\,L_\theta\bigr),
\]
with \(\rho_\theta\) a density operator.  For a pure state \(\rho_\theta=\lvert\psi_\theta\rangle\!\langle\psi_\theta\rvert\),
\[
L_\theta=2\Bigl(\lvert\partial_\theta\psi_\theta\rangle\!\langle\psi_\theta\rvert+\lvert\psi_\theta\rangle\!\langle\partial_\theta\psi_\theta\rvert\Bigr),
\]
and \(L_\theta\) plays the role of a **quantum score operator** generating the quantum Fisher information.  This is a linear operator, not a ket, but it generalises the classical score in the same way that density operators generalise probability densities.

### Bottom line
* A **ket** is a full quantum state (modulus + phase).
* The **classical score** matches only the gradient of the modulus of that state.
* The **quantum score operator** (SLD) provides the faithful quantum counterpart, but it is an operator, not a vector.

So while they touch at the level of the wavefunction’s *modulus*, a ket as a whole has more structure than any classical score function captures.
